This perovskite material with high fluores­
cence efficiency was used to make LEDs.
Appropriate thin film deposition technology is of great sig­
nificance for obtaining high­quality optoelectronic devices.
Two common methods are spin coating and chemical vapor
deposition. For obtaining perovskite thin films by spin coating,
organic halide AX and bivalent metal halide BX
) are dissolved in organic solvents to form precursor
solutions, which are then spin casted or dropped onto different
matrices and annealed to form perovskite thin films. It is very
important to choose the appropriate processing time and tem­
perature based on different precursor compositions for the
needed crystallinity, phase state, and morphology of perovskite
Some important research results are presented here.
and then the solution was spin coated on a quartz substrate to
3 to 100 nm, affected by the precursor concentration and the
spin­coating speed. Atomically thin uniform 2D square perov­
was reported by Yang’s group in 2015.

strate and heated to dry under 75
C. When a mixed solvent of

the obtained products were thick and randomly distributed on
the substrate. When acetonitrile was introduced to form a ter­
nary mixed solvent, uniform square perovskite sheets grew on
